title: 107_s2449
content: The Act titled "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" allows federal payments under Medicaid for emergency medical conditions of certain aliens. The Social Security Act is amended to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions of aliens, pregnancy-related services, and conditions that may complicate pregnancy. The Social Security Act is amended to include services for emergency medical conditions of aliens, pregnancy-related services, and testing or treatment for communicable diseases for certain aliens without residency requirements. The Immigration and Nationality Act applies residency requirements to aliens receiving medical assistance under the State plan, effective upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is amended to provide $25,000,000 for fiscal years 1998 through 2001 and $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. State allotments determination is also revised. The funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is amended to provide $25,000,000 for fiscal years 1998 through 2001 and $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall compute an allotment for each of the 15 States with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The allotment for each State is based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in the State compared to the total percentage for all States. Any unutilized allotment can be used for payment in the future. The unutilized allotment for a fiscal year can be carried over to the subsequent fiscal year. The percentage of undocumented aliens in a State is determined based on the most recent estimates prepared by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The Statistics Division of the Immigration and Naturalization Service is involved in amending Section 4723(c) of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 to require the use of funds to assist hospitals and providers of emergency health services for undocumented aliens. The State plan, submitted to the Secretary, outlines the allocation of funds to hospitals and providers of emergency health services for undocumented aliens in areas impacted by health costs related to undocumented aliens. Payments are based on each eligible hospital's or provider's payments under the approved State plan. The State plan allocates funds to hospitals and providers for emergency medical services for undocumented aliens based on their payments under the plan. Definitions and special rules apply for this subsection. Definitions and special rules apply to subsection regarding hospitals and providers for emergency medical services for undocumented aliens. The term 'hospital' is defined as in the Social Security Act, 'provider' includes physicians and health care professionals, and a provider is considered related to a hospital if they furnish emergency health services to the same individual. The subsection specifies that payments for emergency health services provided by a hospital cannot replace federal payments to states under the Social Security Act for emergency medical services. States are also restricted from using these payments for other purposes. The amendments made by this section, as described in section 1903(v)(2)(A) of the Social Security Act, apply starting from fiscal year 2003. Permitting states and localities to provide health care to all individuals starting from fiscal year 2003. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to remove certain paragraphs in subsections (b) and (c), and make redesignations. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to exclude health benefits provided by state or local government agencies or appropriated funds. The amendments apply to health care provided before, on, or after the enactment of the Act.
